title: The One With The Race Car Bed

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: Central Perk, the whole gang is there, Ross is telling a story about what
happened at work and the rest of the gang are thinking to themselves, denoted by italics.]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: So I told Carl, ‘Nobody, no matter how famous their parents are, nobody is allowed to climb on the dinosaur.’ But of course this went in one ear and out.....

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I love how he cares so much about stuff. If I squint I can pretend he’s Alan Alda.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Oh good, another dinosaur story. When are those gonna become extinct?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: If I was a superhero who could fly and be invisible, that would be the best.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: What does Rachel see in this guy? I love Rachel. I wish she was my wife.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Who’s singing?

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: Central Perk, the whole gang is there, Ross is telling a story about what
happened at work and the rest of the gang are thinking to themselves, denoted by italics.]

events.event_description: Ross tells the group about telling Carl that nobody is allowed to climb on the dinosaur at work.
Rachel comments on Ross's concern for his work and humorously compares him to Alan Alda.
Monica makes a sarcastic remark about dinosaur stories becoming extinct.
Chandler expresses a hypothetical desire to have superpowers, flying and invisibility.
Gunther questions Rachel's attraction to Ross and expresses admiration for Rachel.
Phoebe asks who is singing, indicating she hears singing during the scene.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's, the whole gang is there including Janice, they’re
watching Happy Days .]

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hey. When you guys were kids and you played Happy Days , who were you? I was always Richie.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: I was always Joanne.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Question. Was ah, ‘Egg the Gellers!’ the war cry of your neighbourhood?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ewww! Oh! It’s the Mattress King!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Booo!!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (to Janice) Don’t look honey. Change the channel! Change the channel!

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Wait! Wait! I wanna see this. After I divorce him, half of that kingdom is gonna be mine.

dialogue.speaker: MATRESS KING
dialogue.text: (on TV) ‘Despair fills the mattress showroom. My kingdom is suddenly without a queen. I’m so depressed I’m going to slash... my prices!! Check it out! Four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set! I’m going medieval on prices!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: What a wank!

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Oh, I cannot believe he’s using our divorce to sell mattresses.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: I know! And four ninety-nine for a pillow top queen set, who cares about the divorce, those babies will sell themselves. (they all stare at her) And I’m appalled for you by the way.

dialogue.speaker: MATRESS KING
dialogue.text: (on TV) I’m close. I’m cheap. I’m the king.

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's, the whole gang is there including Janice, they’re
watching Happy Days .]

events.event_description: Ross asks the group which character they identified with in Happy Days, revealing his own identification as Richie.
Monica states she was always Joanne in Happy Days.
Joey questions if 'Egg the Gellers!' was the neighborhood war cry, implying curiosity about local customs.
Phoebe exclaims 'Ewww!' upon noticing the Mattress King on TV, indicating surprise or disgust.
Chandler tells Janice to change the channel to avoid watching the Mattress King.
Janice insists on watching the TV segment about the Mattress King, expressing interest after her divorce.
The Mattress King on TV announces a mattress sale, claiming his 'kingdom' is without a queen due to divorce.
Chandler comments 'What a wank!' in response to the Mattress King's sales pitch.
Janice expresses her disbelief that the Mattress King is using her divorce to promote mattresses.
Monica comments on the mattress sale price and dismisses the divorce as irrelevant to the sales pitch.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Rachel is on the phone, everyone else is there except Joey.]

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: ‘Okay. (listens) Okay, daddy we’ll see you tomorrow night. (listens) Okay bye-bye.’ (hangs up)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: We?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Are ah, having dinner with my Dad tomorrow night, I hope that’s okay.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh shoot, tomorrow’s not so good, I’m supposed to um, fall off the Empire State building and land on a bicycle with no seat. Sorry.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Ross, my father doesn’t hate you.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Please, he refers to me as ‘wethead’.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: But honey he calls everybody by a nickname! Okay, look, I know, all right, just one dinner, please, just one night for me, please. I just want him to love you like I do. (Ross looks at her) All right, well not exactly like I do, but, but, if you do come to dinner, I’ll love you like I do in that black thing that you like.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: (leaning in) I’ll go.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hi Gunther.

dialogue.speaker: GUNTHER
dialogue.text: Yeah, we’ll see!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: (entering) Hey, you guys!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Hey!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Guess what?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: I got a gig!

dialogue.speaker: ALL
dialogue.text: Yay!!

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: See, that’s why I could never be an actor. Because I can’t say gig.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Yeah, I can’t say croissant. (realises) Oh my God!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: What’s the part?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well, it’s not a part, no. I’m teaching acting for soap operas down at the Learning Extension.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Come on! That’s great.

dialogue.speaker: ALL
dialogue.text: Wow!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Yeah, yeah. It’s like my chance to give something back to the acting community.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Y’know your probably not allowed to sleep with any of your students.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: (glares at him) I know!

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Rachel is on the phone, everyone else is there except Joey.]

events.event_description: Rachel ends her phone call with her father, saying goodbye.
Rachel informs Ross about having dinner with her dad tomorrow night.
Ross declines the dinner invitation, joking about falling off the Empire State Building onto a bicycle.
Rachel assures Ross that her father doesn't hate him and explains he calls everyone by nicknames.
Rachel pleads with Ross to attend the dinner so her father will love him.
Chandler volunteers to go to the dinner with Rachel and Ross.
Joey enters the scene and announces he got a gig.
Joey shares that he is teaching acting for soap operas at the Learning Extension.
Ross comments that Joey is probably not allowed to sleep with his students, and Joey glares at him.
The group reacts with enthusiasm to Joey's new gig.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Mattress King, Monica and Phoebe are shopping for a new mattress.]

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ugh! I don’t know Monica. It feels funny just being here. I mean if you buy a bed from Janice’s ex-husband, that’s like betraying Chandler.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Not at these prices.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: (sees a little kid playing with a race car bed) (to kid) Hi. Y'know in England this car would be on the other side of the store. (the kid just stares at her, and she makes the ‘that went right over your head’ motion) Woo!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (lying down on a mattress) Oh! Ohhhhh! Oh! Phoebe, come here. Aw, this is my new bed. You gotta feel this bad boy.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Eh, Monica it, it feels so weird, y'know, Chandler’s your friend... (hops onto the bed) Oh! Oh my God! Aw, all right take this bed, you can make other friends.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Mattress King, Monica and Phoebe are shopping for a new mattress.]

events.event_description: Phoebe expresses discomfort about shopping at Mattress King and mentions the potential betrayal of Chandler if Monica buys a bed from Janice's ex-husband.
Phoebe notices a little kid playing with a race car bed and greets him, making a joke about the car being on the other side of the store in England.
Monica lies down on a mattress and calls Phoebe over to feel it, indicating her approval of the bed.
Phoebe hops onto the mattress and comments on how it feels weird, mentioning Chandler's relationship with Monica.
Phoebe jokingly suggests that Monica can make other friends if she takes the bed, implying a humorous comment about relationships.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: Classroom. Joey is writing his name on the board, but turns around before
he’s done which causes him to write his name with a downward curve, and he then
underlines it, and draws the line right through his name.]

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Good evening. I’m Mr. Tribbiani. And I will be teaching acting for soap operas. Now um, on my first day as (proudly) Dr. Drake Remoray on Days of Our Lives , (looks for a reaction from his students, and gets none.) I learned that one of the most important things in soap opera acting is reacting, this does not mean acting again, it means, you don’t have a line, but someone else just did. And it goes like this. (looks all intense for a moment and then gasps, the students cheer him) Thanks, thanks, a lot. Oh, by the way, before I forget to work in soap operas some of you will have to become much more attractive. All right, moving right along.

scenes.location: Classroom. Joey is writing his name on the board
scenes.event_description:
[Scene: Classroom. Joey is writing his name on the board, but turns around before
he’s done which causes him to write his name with a downward curve, and he then
underlines it, and draws the line right through his name.]

events.event_description: Joey writes his name on the classroom board, starting to write with a downward curve.
Joey turns around before completing writing his name, causing the name to be written with a downward curve.
Joey underlines his name on the board.
Joey draws a line through his name on the board.
Joey introduces himself as Mr. Tribbiani and states he will be teaching acting for soap operas.
Joey mentions his role as Dr. Drake Remoray on Days of Our Lives and seeks a reaction from the students.
Joey demonstrates the importance of reacting in soap opera acting by explaining the concept to the students.
Joey gasps dramatically to emphasize his point about reacting in acting.
The students cheer Joey after his dramatic gasp.
Joey comments on the need for students to become more attractive to work in soap operas.

scenes.scene_description:
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Joey is entering, Phoebe is already there waiting for the
delievery guy.]

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hi!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Hey! Ooh! How was teaching last night?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Oh it was great. Yeah, you get to say stuff like, ’Hey, the bell doesn’t dismiss you, I dismiss you.’

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Ooooh, nice.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Oh, and guess what, I got an audition for All My Children .

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh, yay!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Yeah, it’s this great part, this boxer named Nick. And I’m so, so right for it, y'know, he’s just like me. Except he’s a boxer, and has an evil twin.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh. (goes and answers the door and there is this huge black delievery guy.)

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: Dom da-da dom! Here ye! Here ye! Delivery from the Mattress King. (to Phoebe) You Miss Geller?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: Sign here. (hands her a clipboard)

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh, do I have a middle name. All right Monica Velula Geller. It’s that bedroom there. (points to Monica’s room)

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey, Monica bought a bed from the Mattress King?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Yeah, so please, please, please, don’t say anything to Chandler.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: You want me to lie to Chandler?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Is that a problem?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh, hey, hey Nick the boxer let’s see what you got. All right ya, put ‘em up. Come on. (they start shadow boxing)

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey, you’re ah, pretty good at this.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Yeah, well I had to learn, I was staying at the Y and some off the young men weren’t acting Christian enough.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Ahh!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey now!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey!!! Oww!! And I’m bleeding.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh! Oh! Oh!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Okay, great.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Wow! And I’m a vegetarian! All right, all right, well I’m sorry, we’ll put some ice on it.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: ‘Kay, put your head back.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: All right. I can’t see.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: All right, I have ya. Oh God.

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: Which bedroom do ya want it in Miss Geller?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Oh, it’s the compulsively neat one by the window, okay.

dialogue.speaker: GUY
dialogue.text: Gotcha. (he and his helper walk in carrying the racecar bed.)

scenes.event_description:
[Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Joey is entering, Phoebe is already there waiting for the
delievery guy.]

events.event_description: Joey enters Monica and Rachel's apartment and greets Phoebe.
Phoebe asks Joey about his teaching experience from the previous night.
Joey shares with Phoebe that he had a great teaching experience and quotes a line he used.
Joey announces to Phoebe that he got an audition for 'All My Children' and describes his character.
Phoebe answers the door and interacts with the delivery person, signing for the delivery.
Phoebe informs the delivery person that Monica bought a bed from the Mattress King and gives directions to Monica's bedroom.
Phoebe asks Joey to keep the delivery of the bed a secret from Chandler.
Joey agrees to keep the secret about the bed delivery from Chandler.
Phoebe and Joey engage in a playful shadow boxing session, with Phoebe encouraging Joey to fight.
Joey gets injured during shadow boxing and notices bleeding, prompting Phoebe to assist him with ice.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Restaurant, Rachel and Ross and Dr. Green are having dinner.]

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Hi Daddy!

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: This where they put it? What, there no table available in the kitchen! Hello, baby.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: You remember Ross.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Um-hmm.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Nice to see you again Dr. Green.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: So! (they both try to sit next to Rachel but Dr. Green is successful.) (to Ross) How’s the library?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Ugh, museum.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: What happened to the library?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: There never was a library. I mean there are libraries, its just that I ah, I never worked at one.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: You know what’s really good here, the lobster. What do you say shall I just order three.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Yeah, if you’re really hungry. (Dr. Green stares at him) It was a joke, I made a joke.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah, actually Daddy Ross is allergic to lobster.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: What kind of person is allergic to lobster? I guess the kind of person that works at a library.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: It’s not a library...

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: (interrupting him) I know!! It’s a museum! What, you’re the only one around here who can make a joke! At least mine was funny. Ah, waiter, we will have two lobsters and a menu. (nods at Ross, and mouths I don’t know to the waiter.)

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Restaurant, Rachel and Ross and Dr. Green are having dinner.]

events.event_description: Rachel greets her father, Dr. Green, upon his arrival at the restaurant.
Dr. Green attempts to sit next to Rachel but is unsuccessful, and Ross succeeds in sitting next to her.
Dr. Green asks Ross about his work, and Ross responds that he works at a museum, implying he does not work at a library.
Dr. Green suggests ordering three lobsters, implying he wants to order for everyone.
Ross jokes that he is not hungry enough to eat three lobsters, prompting Dr. Green to stare at him.
Rachel informs Dr. Green that Ross is allergic to lobster.
Dr. Green questions what kind of person is allergic to lobster, jokingly suggesting it's someone who works at a library.
Ross clarifies that he does not work at a library, indicating a correction to Dr. Green's joke.
Dr. Green interrupts Ross to affirm that he believes Ross's correction and makes a joke about being funny.
Dr. Green orders two lobsters and a menu from the waiter, indicating his decision to order lobsters for the group.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: So, Dr. Green, how’s the old boat.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: They found rust. You know what rust does to a boat?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: It gives it a nice antiquey look.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: (he stares at Ross) Rust, is boat cancer, Ross.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Wow. I’m sorry, when I was a kid I lost a bike to that. (Rachel giggles at that)

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Excuse me for a moment, will you please, I want to say good night to the Levines, before we go.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Okay! (picks up a knife and pretends to stab his heart.)

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Aw honey stop! It’s not that bad.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Yeah. (sees the bill) Op! Uh-oh! I think your Dad must’ve added wrong. He only tipped like four percent.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah. That’s Daddy.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: That’s Daddy?! But doesn’t it bother you? You’re a waitress.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yes, it bothers me Ross, but y'know if he was a regular at the coffee house, I’d be serving him sneezers.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: So?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: So. Ross, I’ve bugged him about this a million times, he’s not gonna change.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: You really serve people sneezers?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well um, I don’t.

dialogue.speaker: DR GREEN
dialogue.text: You kids ready?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Thanks again, Dr. Green.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: All right.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Oh, wait, wait, wait, wait, I think I forgot my receipt.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh, ah, you don’t need that.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: The carbon, it’s messy, I mean it gets on your fingers and causes, the, the ah, night blindness.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: (gets his receipt and notices the twenty) What is this? Who put a twenty down here? Huh?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh, yeah, that would be me, um, I have, I have a problem I-I tip way too much, way, way, too much, it’s a sickness really.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah it is, it is. (to Ross) We really, really have to do something about that.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Excuse me, you think I’m cheap?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Oh Daddy, no he didn’t mean anything by that, he really didn’t.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Nothing I do means anything, really.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: This is nice. I pay two hundred dollars for dinner, you put down twenty, and you come out looking like Mr. Big Shot. You really want to be Mr. Big Shot? Here, I’ll tell you what, you pay the whole bill, Mr. Big Shot, all right. (rips up the bill, and throws it at Ross, then leaves)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Well Mr. Big Shot is better than ‘wethead’.

events.event_description: Ross asks Dr. Green about the condition of his boat after dinner.
Dr. Green explains that rust is like boat cancer, implying it damages the boat.
Ross jokes that rust gives the boat an antiquey look.
Dr. Green stares at Ross and clarifies that rust is like cancer for a boat.
Ross pretends to stab his heart with a knife in a humorous gesture.
Rachel giggles at Ross's joke about losing a bike to rust.
Ross notices the bill and comments that his father-in-law added a small tip, implying dissatisfaction.
Rachel defends her father, saying he is not going to change his tipping habits.
Ross admits he tends to tip excessively, calling it a sickness.
Dr. Green confronts Ross about his tip, rips up the bill, and leaves angrily.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Classroom, Joey is lecturing on facial expressions.]

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Okay, some tricks of the trade. Now, I’ve never been able to cry as an actor, so if I’m in a scene where I have to cry, I cut a hole in my pocket, take a pair of tweezers, and just start pulling. Or ah, or, let’s say I wanna convey that I’ve just done something evil. That would be the basic ‘I have a fishhook in my eyebrow and I like it’ (Does it by raising one eyebrow, and showing off the pretend fishhook.) Okay, let’s say I’ve just gotten bad news, well all I do there is try and divide 232 by 13. (looks all confused) And that’s how it’s done. Great soap opera acting tonight everybody, class dismissed.

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: Hey, Mr. Trib.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Hey-hey.

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: Guess what, I got an audition!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Awww, one of my students got an audition. I’m so proud.

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: I was wondering if you would consider coaching me for it?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: You bet! What’s the part?

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: Oh it’s great, it’s a role on All My Children , Nick the boxer.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Classroom, Joey is lecturing on facial expressions.]

events.event_description: Joey demonstrates a comedic method of pretending to cry by pulling a hole in his pocket with tweezers.
Joey explains how to convey evil by raising one eyebrow and pretending to have a fishhook in his eyebrow.
Joey describes how to simulate emotional distress by dividing 232 by 13, then looks confused.
Joey dismisses the class after concluding his lecture on acting tricks.
The student approaches Joey and announces they have an audition.
Joey expresses pride upon hearing about the student's audition.
The student asks Joey if he will coach them for the audition.
Joey agrees to coach the student and asks about the role.
The student reveals the role is Nick the boxer on All My Children.
Joey responds positively to the student's news about the role.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Hallway, Ross and Rachel are returning from dinner.]

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: You had to do it, didn’t you? You couldn’t just leave it alone.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Four percent. Okay. I tip more than that when there’s a bug in my food.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Ross, tonight was about the two of you getting along. (Ross groans and rubs his neck) Oh, would you just see my chiropractor, already.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Yeah, I’m gonna go to a doctor who went to school in a mini-mall.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hey Pheebs, what are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I’m, I’m freaking out! Monica kinda trusted me with something and she shouldn’t have! All right, I haven’t lived here in a while, so I have to ask you something. Does Monica still turn on the lights in her bedroom?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Um. yeah.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I am soo dead. (goes to Monica’s room)

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: All right, look, here’s the bottom line Ross, this is fixable, if we act fast, okay. So, I’ll invite him to brunch tomorrow and you can make nice.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Look, honey, I have tried to make nice, it doesn’t work.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Okay, look, Ross, I realise that my Father is difficult, but that’s why you have got to be the bigger man here.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Look sweetie, I could be the bigger man, I could be the biggest man, I could be a big, huge, giant man, and it still wouldn’t make any difference, except that I could pick your Father up and say ‘Like me! Like me tiny doctor!’

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Okay, well can’t you just try it one more time Ross? For me? For me?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Rachel one brunch is not gonna solve anything. You gotta face it, okay we’re never gonna get along.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Okay, well you are just gonna have too, okay. Because I already got a Mother and a Father who cannot stay in the same room together, okay, I don’t wanna have to have a separate room for you too!! (starts to cry)

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Okay, okay, okay. (hugs her) I’ll get the bagels.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Hallway, Ross and Rachel are returning from dinner.]

events.event_description: Ross and Rachel return to the hallway after dinner, engaging in a conversation about Ross's behavior and their relationship with Rachel's father.
Rachel expresses concern about Ross's actions affecting their relationship and suggests inviting him to brunch to improve relations.
Ross dismisses the idea that a brunch will resolve their issues, asserting that they will never get along with Rachel's father.
Rachel pleads with Ross to try one more time for her sake, emphasizing her emotional distress.
Rachel begins to cry, expressing her frustration about her family dynamics and her fear of having to separate her relationship with Ross from her parents' conflicts.
Ross comforts Rachel by hugging her and agrees to get bagels, signaling a moment of reconciliation.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Monica’s bedroom, Phoebe is trying to hide the bed from Monica.]

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (sees the bed) What’s this?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Isn’t it cool! Varoom! Varoom!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: This is not the bed I ordered!

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I know, you must’ve won like a contest or something!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Phoebe!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Why is this car in my bedroom?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: I’m sorry, okay, I-I wasn’t looking, and the store says that they won’t take it back because you signed for it...

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: When did I sign for it?

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: When I was you! Y'know what, it’s all Joey’s fault, ‘cause he left his nose open!

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Did you make brownies today?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Knock, knock.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: (to Phoebe) Quick, take off your dress, he won’t notice the bed.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Hey, I’m going for sushi does anybody want.. (enters and sees the bed) Whoa-whoa, somebody missed the off ramp.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: It’s Monica’s bed. What?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Okay. (to Monica) It’s a racecar.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: So. This has always been Monica’s bed, what you’re just noticing now, how self-involved are you?

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Okay, well it this bed isn’t new, how come there is plastic on the mattress?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Sometimes I have bad dreams. (starts to break down, and Phoebe offers her, her hand to comfort her.)

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Monica’s bedroom, Phoebe is trying to hide the bed from Monica.]

events.event_description: Phoebe attempts to hide the bed from Monica in her bedroom.
Monica notices the bed and questions Phoebe about it.
Phoebe explains that Monica might have won the bed in a contest and admits she wasn't looking when she bought it.
Monica questions why there is a car in her bedroom.
Phoebe blames Joey for leaving his nose open, which led to the store refusing to take back the car.
Monica asks Phoebe if she made brownies today.
Chandler enters and comments on the bed, comparing it to a racecar.
Chandler notices the plastic on the mattress and questions why it is there if the bed isn't new.
Monica reveals she sometimes has bad dreams and begins to break down emotionally.
Phoebe offers her hand to comfort Monica as she starts to cry.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Classroom, Joey is coaching his student.]

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: Look, I just saw my best friends brains smeared across the canvas, that’s not gonna be me, not me.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Wow! That was good. That was...(points to his pocket) Tweezers?

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Whoa. That was really good.

dialogue.speaker: STUDENT
dialogue.text: Thanks, any suggestions?

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Classroom, Joey is coaching his student.]

events.event_description: Student expresses fear about becoming violent after witnessing a traumatic event involving his friends' brains smeared across a canvas.
Joey responds with surprise and comments on the student's statement, then points to his pocket, implying he is asking about tweezers.
Student clarifies that the item Joey pointed to is not tweezers.
Joey expresses approval of the student's previous statement, indicating he found it impressive or convincing.
Student thanks Joey and asks for suggestions, indicating a desire for guidance or advice.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Chandler, Monica, and Phoebe are there, yelling at Joey.]

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You told him to play the boxer gay!!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Well, I-I might’ve said supergay.

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: You totally screwed him over.

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Joey, you’re this guy’s teacher. I mean how could you do this?

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Because, Monica, the guy’s so good, and I really, really want this part.

dialogue.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogue.text: Well, if you really, really want it, then it’s okay.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Central Perk, Chandler, Monica, and Phoebe are there, yelling at Joey.]

events.event_description: Chandler accuses Joey of telling someone to play the boxer gay.
Joey admits he might have said 'supergay' to the actor.
Chandler states that Joey completely screwed over the actor.
Monica questions Joey about how he could do this as the actor's teacher.
Joey explains that he wants the part because the actor is very good.
Phoebe comments that if Joey really wants the part, then it's okay.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Rachel is greeting her Father for their brunch.]

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: (opening the door) Hi Daddy.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Baby. Ross.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Dr. Green. How are you? (offers his hand, and Dr. Green puts his scarf on it.)

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Thanks for dinner last night.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Thank you for teaching me a valuable lesson.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Nice hair. What’d ya do? Swim here?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: (to Rachel) Okay, that’s it, I can’t take it anymore.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What? What? He’s interested in you. He-he likes your hair, he just wants to know how you got here.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh, please. Sweetie it’s hopeless, okay, I’m just gonna go. (starts to leave rubbing his neck)

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What?!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Look, look I’m sorry. It’s just that....

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Ross? What’s with the neck?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: He’s got this thing. And I keep telling him to go to my chiropractor...

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: You’re still going to that chiropractor, that man couldn’t get into medical school in Extapa!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Thank you! That’s what I keep saying.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Excuse me, Dr. Bobby happens to be an excellent doctor.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Uh.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, his name is Dr. Bobby?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Well that’s his last name.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: And his first name.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: He’s Bobby Bobby?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: It’s Robert Bobby.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: And um, excuse me, he helps me.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Oh-ho please. Ask her how?

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: What do you need help for?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: With my alignment. I’ve got one leg shorter than the other.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Oh God!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Argue with that.

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: What? It’s true, my right leg is two inches shorter.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Come on! You’re just titling! (to Ross) Her legs are fine!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: I know that!

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: So, why do you let her go to a chiropractor for?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: I’m sorry, let her?

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: What can I do, she doesn’t listen to me about renter’s insurance either.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, you don’t have renter’s insurance?!

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: Well what if somebody steals something? How are you gonna run after him with one leg shorter than the other?!

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Hey, would you ah, would you like some juice?

dialogue.speaker: DR. GREEN
dialogue.text: I’d love some juice. Thanks.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Okay. (to Rachel) Wow! This is going so well. Did you see us? Did you see?

dialogue.speaker: RACHEL
dialogue.text: Yeah honey, I’m standing right there! Why didn’t you just tell him about the mole I haven’t got checked yet.

dialogue.speaker: ROSS
dialogue.text: Excellent!

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Monica and Rachel's, Rachel is greeting her Father for their brunch.]

events.event_description: Rachel opens the door and greets her father, Dr. Green.
Ross greets Dr. Green and offers his hand, which Dr. Green puts his scarf on.
Dr. Green thanks Ross for dinner from the previous night.
Ross responds to Dr. Green by thanking him for teaching him a valuable lesson.
Rachel comments to Ross that Dr. Green is interested in him and notices he likes his hair.
Ross decides to leave the scene, rubbing his neck as he announces he can't take it anymore.
Rachel questions Ross about his reaction, suggesting Dr. Green is interested in him.
Ross apologizes to Rachel and indicates he is about to leave due to discomfort.
Dr. Green notices Ross's neck and asks about it.
Rachel explains that Ross has a neck issue and mentions her chiropractor.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Classroom, Joey is talking to his students.]

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: (sadly) There will come a time in each of your careers when you’ll have a chance to screw over another soap opera actor. I had such an opportunity in the recent, present. And I’m ashamed to say that I took it, I advised a fellow actor to play a role, homosexually. Yeah, we both auditioned for the part, and uh, as it turned out, they ah, they liked the stupid gay thing and cast him. And now, he’s got a two year contract opposite Susan Luchhi, the first lady of daytime television, and me, me I’m stuck here teaching a bunch of people, most of whom are too ugly to even be on TV. I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I’m sorry. (he gets a huge round of applause from his students.) Thank you.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Classroom, Joey is talking to his students.]

events.event_description: Joey begins his lecture in the classroom, addressing his students.
Joey admits to having had an opportunity to undermine another soap opera actor and took it.
Joey advises a fellow actor to play a role homosexually.
Joey explains that both he and the fellow actor auditioned for the same part.
Joey reveals that the casting directors liked the gay portrayal and cast his colleague.
Joey states that his colleague now has a two-year contract opposite Susan Luchhi.
Joey expresses his frustration about being stuck teaching students who are not attractive enough for TV.
Joey apologizes multiple times for his previous statements.
Joey receives a large round of applause from his students for his honesty.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Mattress King, Monica is trying to return her bed.]

dialogue.speaker: JESTER
dialogue.text: Uh, may I help you?

dialogue.speaker: MONICA
dialogue.text: Yeah, I talked to you on the phone, I’m the lady that got stuck with the racecar bed.

dialogue.speaker: JESTER
dialogue.text: Look, it’s like I told you, there’s nothing I can do. You signed for it, Monica Velula Geller.

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: All right, Jester man, look we wanna see the king.

dialogue.speaker: JESTER
dialogue.text: Nobody sees the king!

dialogue.speaker: JOEY
dialogue.text: Oh-ho-kay, I’m talking to the king. (starts to go to a back room)

dialogue.speaker: JESTER
dialogue.text: Hey! You can’t go back there!

dialogue.speaker: JANICE
dialogue.text: Oh my God.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Mattress King, Monica is trying to return her bed.]

events.event_description: Monica identifies herself to Jester and explains she is returning a racecar bed she received.
Jester informs Monica that she signed for the bed and claims there is nothing he can do to help her.
Joey demands to see the king at Mattress King.
Jester refuses Joey's request, stating that nobody sees the king.
Joey attempts to go to the back room to see the king, starting to walk in that direction.
Jester stops Joey from proceeding to the back room, telling him he cannot go there.
Janice reacts with surprise or shock upon witnessing Joey's attempt to see the king.

scenes.scene_description: [Scene: Monica’s bedroom, Chandler is playing with the bed.]

dialogue.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogue.text: Varrrrrroom! Hey! Watch it lady! Varrrrrrrrrrom! (makes a screeching sound as he pretends to stomp on the brakes.) Hey-hey good lookin’! (honks the bed’s little horn on the steering wheel.) Varrrrrrrrroom. (notices Rachel and stops) All right, I’ll leave. My bed’s so boring.

scenes.event_description: [Scene: Monica’s bedroom, Chandler is playing with the bed.]

events.event_description: Chandler enters Monica's bedroom and begins playing with the bed, pretending to drive a vehicle by making engine sounds and honking the bed’s horn.
Chandler makes engine noises and pretends to brake, demonstrating playful behavior with the bed.
Chandler notices Rachel entering the scene and stops his playful activity.
Chandler announces he will leave because he finds his bed boring.
